title: Making a TED-Ed Lesson: Visualizing complex ideas

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge that illustrators face when trying to explain complex and difficult concepts?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the perfect description to convey an idea

options.label: B
options.text: Creating charts and stats to relay information

options.label: C
options.text: Using visual metaphors to bring concepts to life

options.label: D
options.text: Designing characters and environments for an animation

multiple-choice.question: What is a visual metaphor, and how is it used in illustration?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual metaphor is a description that relates one object to another, and it is used to suggest a particular association or point of similarity.

options.label: B
options.text: A visual metaphor is a type of chart or stat, and it is used to relay complex information.

options.label: C
options.text: A visual metaphor is a style of animation, and it is used to create memorable visuals.

options.label: D
options.text: A visual metaphor is a type of written description, and it is used to explain emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is Big Data, and why is it a challenging concept to depict visually?

options.label: A
options.text: Big Data is a type of computer network, and it is challenging to depict because it is intangible.

options.label: B
options.text: Big Data is a huge amount of digital information produced worldwide on a daily basis, and it is challenging to depict because it is complex and difficult to explain.

options.label: C
options.text: Big Data is a type of animation style, and it is challenging to depict because it is abstract.

options.label: D
options.text: Big Data is a type of visual metaphor, and it is challenging to depict because it is elusive.

multiple-choice.question: How do illustrators use visual development to design characters and environments for an animation?

options.label: A
options.text: By thinking of an appropriate and appealing style to illustrate the ideas and help the viewer better understand what they're hearing.

options.label: B
options.text: By creating charts and stats to relay information.

options.label: C
options.text: By using visual metaphors to bring concepts to life.

options.label: D
options.text: By designing characters and environments without considering the style or era of the animation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using graphic representations to capture the interest of an audience?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the audience to understand complex information more easily.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a memorable visual that communicates an idea more effectively.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a type of visual metaphor that suggests a particular association or point of similarity.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a style of animation that influences future generations of animators.

options.label: C
options.text: To react with acids and create carbon dioxide gas

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: A reaction that adds flavor to the cookies, occurring at 350 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: B
options.text: A reaction that creates a crunchy texture, starting at 350 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A reaction that adds flavor to the cookies, starting at 390 degrees Fahrenheit.

options.label: D

title: What are stem cells? - Craig A. Kohn

multiple-choice.question: What are stem cells, and what makes them unique?

options.label: A
options.text: Stem cells are specialized cells with specific jobs or functions.

options.label: B
options.text: Stem cells are undifferentiated cells with no specific job or function but have the potential to become all other kinds of cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Stem cells are only found in embryos and are used for research purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: Stem cells are only used to treat blood diseases such as leukemia.

multiple-choice.question: What is regenerative medicine, and how does it relate to stem cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of stem cells to create new tissue to replace damaged bodily tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of stem cells to treat only blood diseases such as leukemia.

options.label: C
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of embryonic stem cells to create new organs.

options.label: D
options.text: Regenerative medicine is the use of tissue-specific stem cells to create new tissue.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three types of stem cells mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Adult stem cells, embryonic stem cells, and blood stem cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Adult stem cells, embryonic stem cells, and induced pluripotent stem cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Tissue-specific stem cells, embryonic stem cells, and skin stem cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Adult stem cells, tissue-specific stem cells, and induced pluripotent stem cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using stem cells to create new tissue?

options.label: A
options.text: To create personalized medicine that is specific to each individual's body.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a cure for all diseases.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how the body works.

options.label: D
options.text: To create new organs for transplantation.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists hope to use stem cells in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Only to treat blood diseases such as leukemia.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop specialized medicine and to better understand how the body functions.

options.label: C
options.text: To create new organs for transplantation.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a cure for all diseases.

title: Origins of religion

multiple-choice.question: How did Stone Age people view the universe?

options.text: As vast, complex, and governed by natural laws

options.label: B
options.text: As flat, small, and under the sky

options.label: C
options.text: As a collection of separate, unconnected worlds

options.label: D
options.text: As a place of constant change and evolution

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That they were interconnected, but distinct entities

options.label: C
options.text: That there was no defined difference between them

options.label: D
options.text: That materiality was the only reality

options.label: A
options.text: As the result of natural laws and processes

options.label: B
options.text: As the result of magic and spirits

options.label: C
options.text: As the result of human actions and decisions

options.label: D
options.text: As the result of chance and randomness

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of storytelling in Stone Age societies?

options.label: A
options.text: To entertain and engage the audience

options.label: B
options.text: To convey historical facts and events

options.label: C
options.text: To describe the world in a way that people could understand

options.label: D
options.text: To promote social change and progress

multiple-choice.question: How did Stone Age people view their ability to change the world?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed they had the power to shape their own destiny

options.label: B
options.text: They believed they could influence the gods through magic and ritual

options.label: C
options.text: They tended to believe the world would always be as the gods had made it

options.label: D
